utterances: For me it's not Ward Connelly, it's the…
…in fairness to him, I would say that if the expense money -which is about 700 - two-thirds of it…
…right, is airfare, yada ya yada ya, hotel.
That's fine.
But, the fact…
I don't think it's fine.
Well, if it's actually airfare, you know, and all that kind of - but the fact is that the IRS has been sicked on the NAACP.
Those of us who work in progressive nonprofits know how difficult it is for us to fall under the guidelines.
You can only use a certain percentage for any lobbying activity.
You're not supposed to lobby…
That's right.
…and this is pure lobbying.
So it seems to me that this organization should not be a 501-C3, should be disqualified.
The IRS should be deployed.
And if they don't do this, this does speak to the unlevel playing field.
The fact that the IRS again was sicked on the NAACP suggests the Ward Connelly should be shut down, if not simply imprisoned.
But he has two not-for-profits.
One is a lobbying side, and one is a not-for-profit…
And all together he manages…
…the tax exempt side.
But, you know, the average working family has an income - the average family has an income of about $52,000 a year with two earners.
The average African-American family an income of $30,000.
So for a brother man -brother affirmative action man, or anti-affirmative action man to pick up $276,922 in salary does speak to something.
Now ya'll tell me what.

But the question, Laura - I want you to address this, because our two esteemed colleagues, although their points were well taken, neither of them really did hit the point that I'm trying to get to and whether or not this really makes a difference in the big fight against affirmative action in Michigan.
Well, first of all, let me just remind Michael that superheroes don't get paid anything at all.
When did you ever see Superman get paid on (unintelligible)?
Superman is a fictional character.
All right.
Let's get back to it.
What do you say, Laura?
Is this going to make a difference or not?
(Soundbite of audio dropout)
Oh, we lost it.
…I think in terms of what difference it will make, it won't make any difference.
As Julianne…
(Soundbite of audio dropout)
Oh, is she there?
We lost her?
We lost her.
Okay.
But I will pick up her point and say it won't make a difference.
People will vote on the Michigan civil rights initiative based on their views about the initiative.
And I think the initiative will go down.
All right, I think we have her back.
Are you back, Laura?
No.
Oh, we will.
Not yet.
All right.
Well you, do you agree with that, Julianne, that it's not really going to make a difference?
Or do you think it might?
Even if it's accurate, what is being said.
Even if the IRS were to go in and slap him on the hand or even shut him down.
Do you think it will have an impact on the larger issue?
I've lost her too!
She's gone, too.
I guess, Michael…
You can just talk to me.
…I guess it's just the brothers left for this conversation.
This is what I've been hoping for.
Okay, let's go one-on-one with Tony and Michael!
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, it seems like we've exhausted that topic.
Well, hopefully we will get both of them back before we run out of time.
We've only got a few moments left.
Let's move on to something else, though.

Here in L.A., Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa got himself into some hot water with the Muslim community because he had come out in support of Israel and had not shown - to the Muslim community's point of view - any sympathy towards their concerns.
So there was a meeting last weekend where Villaraigosa met with 10 Muslim leaders and explained that there was a mix-up in his schedule and yada yada yada.
So they seem to have accepted his apology.
My question to you is, you know, what is a big-city mayor to do in a situation like this?
Well, a big-city mayor - any mayor, can't be two-faced.
So the question for me is what is he apologizing for?
He says he's apologizing for a mix-up in his schedule.
Mm hmm.
That's what he says.
Right.
And he got these invitations for interfaith vigils or ceremonies…
Yeah.
…and he said, well, that's my apology.
He didn't say I apologize for standing up for Israel.
He didn't say I apologize for taking the side of Israel against Hezbollah.
He didn't say that.
So you can't - but it gives the appearance - because now he's going, he's saying I apologize to the Muslims, in quotes, it gives the appearance of being two-faced.
So if they're politically independent, I mean, is there evidence that research using the term climate change is actually less likely to get funding from them?
So, my issue is for, and my concern is, look, what do you really believe?
Do you believe that the attacks on Israel were something to say and to object to, which he did?
Or do you now say I have to be more even-handed on the issue?
The question is the issue, it's not the personality.
It's not the schedule of the mayor, because a mayor, he can - and he will - meet with whom he wants.
And the apologies will be empty based on those peoples' view of the issue.
I have good news for you.
I think we have Julianne and we have Laura back.
Are you both back?
I'm back!
We are.
We're…
You mean you just let Michael run his mouth all the time?
You two guys didn't think about us when we were gone.
Tony and Michael!
You know, listen, it's just like Bernie Mac says.
You know, when we break, we break.
And you all went on a break.
And it's time for you to confess.
